trans-unit.source: Storage Services REST API Reference
trans-unit.target: Storage Services REST API Reference

trans-unit.source: The REST APIs for the Windows® Azure™ storage services offer programmatic access to the Blob, Queue, Table, and File services in Azure or in the development environment, via the storage emulator.
trans-unit.target: The REST APIs for the Windows® Azure™ storage services offer programmatic access to the Blob, Queue, Table, and File services in Azure or in the development environment, via the storage emulator.

trans-unit.source: All storage services are accessible via REST APIs.
trans-unit.target: All storage services are accessible via REST APIs.

trans-unit.source: Storage services may be accessed from within a service running in Azure, or directly over the Internet from any application that can send an HTTP/HTTPS request and receive an HTTP/HTTPS response.
trans-unit.target: Storage services may be accessed from within a service running in Azure, or directly over the Internet from any application that can send an HTTP/HTTPS request and receive an HTTP/HTTPS response.

trans-unit.source: The Azure storage services support both HTTP and HTTPS; however, using HTTPS is highly recommended.
trans-unit.target: The Azure storage services support both HTTP and HTTPS; however, using HTTPS is highly recommended.

trans-unit.source: Storage Account
trans-unit.target: Storage Account

trans-unit.source: All access to storage services takes place through the storage account.
trans-unit.target: All access to storage services takes place through the storage account.

trans-unit.source: The storage account is the highest level of the namespace for accessing each of the fundamental services.
trans-unit.target: The storage account is the highest level of the namespace for accessing each of the fundamental services.

trans-unit.source: It is also the basis for authentication.
trans-unit.target: It is also the basis for authentication.

trans-unit.source: The REST APIs for storage services expose the storage account as a resource.
trans-unit.target: The REST APIs for storage services expose the storage account as a resource.

trans-unit.source: To create and manage a storage account, see <legacyLink xlink:href="673cc2bd-6232-4152-9a6f-6d80324d7f87" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Manage Accounts, Subscriptions, and Administrative Roles</legacyLink>.
trans-unit.target: To create and manage a storage account, see <legacyLink xlink:href="673cc2bd-6232-4152-9a6f-6d80324d7f87" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Manage Accounts, Subscriptions, and Administrative Roles</legacyLink>.

trans-unit.source: Blob Service
trans-unit.target: Blob Service

trans-unit.source: The Blob service provides storage for entities, such as binary files and text files.
trans-unit.target: The Blob service provides storage for entities, such as binary files and text files.

trans-unit.source: The REST API for the Blob service exposes two resources: containers and blobs.
trans-unit.target: The REST API for the Blob service exposes two resources: containers and blobs.

trans-unit.source: A container is a set of blobs; every blob must belong to a container.
trans-unit.target: A container is a set of blobs; every blob must belong to a container.

trans-unit.source: The Blob service defines three types of blobs:
trans-unit.target: The Blob service defines three types of blobs:

trans-unit.source: Block blobs, which are optimized for streaming.
trans-unit.target: Block blobs, which are optimized for streaming.

trans-unit.source: This type of blob is the only blob type available with versions prior to 2009-09-19.
trans-unit.target: This type of blob is the only blob type available with versions prior to 2009-09-19.

trans-unit.source: Page blobs, which are optimized for random read/write operations and which provide the ability to write to a range of bytes in a blob.
trans-unit.target: Page blobs, which are optimized for random read/write operations and which provide the ability to write to a range of bytes in a blob.

trans-unit.source: Page blobs are available with version 2009-09-19 and later.
trans-unit.target: Page blobs are available with version 2009-09-19 and later.

trans-unit.source: Append blobs, which are optimized for append operations only.
trans-unit.target: Append blobs, which are optimized for append operations only.

trans-unit.source: Append blobs are available only with version 2015-02-21 and later.
trans-unit.target: Append blobs are available only with version 2015-02-21 and later.

trans-unit.source: Containers and blobs support user-defined metadata in the form of name-value pairs specified as headers on a request operation.
trans-unit.target: Containers and blobs support user-defined metadata in the form of name-value pairs specified as headers on a request operation.

trans-unit.source: Using the REST API for the Blob service, developers can create a hierarchical namespace similar to a file system.
trans-unit.target: Using the REST API for the Blob service, developers can create a hierarchical namespace similar to a file system.

trans-unit.source: Blob names may encode a hierarchy by using a configurable path separator.
trans-unit.target: Blob names may encode a hierarchy by using a configurable path separator.

trans-unit.source: For example, the blob names <placeholder>MyGroup/MyBlob1</placeholder> and <placeholder>MyGroup/MyBlob2</placeholder> imply a virtual level of organization for blobs.
trans-unit.target: For example, the blob names <placeholder>MyGroup/MyBlob1</placeholder> and <placeholder>MyGroup/MyBlob2</placeholder> imply a virtual level of organization for blobs.

trans-unit.source: The enumeration operation for blobs supports traversing the virtual hierarchy in a manner similar to that of a file system, so that you can return a set of blobs that are organized beneath a group.
trans-unit.target: The enumeration operation for blobs supports traversing the virtual hierarchy in a manner similar to that of a file system, so that you can return a set of blobs that are organized beneath a group.

trans-unit.source: For example, you can enumerate all blobs organized under <placeholder>MyGroup/</placeholder>.
trans-unit.target: For example, you can enumerate all blobs organized under <placeholder>MyGroup/</placeholder>.

trans-unit.source: A block blob may be created in one of two ways.
trans-unit.target: A block blob may be created in one of two ways.

trans-unit.source: Block blobs less than or equal to 64 MB in size can be uploaded by calling the <link xlink:href="b213c30f-8d30-4718-ba77-2030f3009719" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Put Blob</link> operation.
trans-unit.target: Block blobs less than or equal to 64 MB in size can be uploaded by calling the <link xlink:href="b213c30f-8d30-4718-ba77-2030f3009719" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Put Blob</link> operation.

trans-unit.source: Block blobs larger than 64 MB must be uploaded as a set of blocks, each of which must be less than or equal to 4 MB in size.
trans-unit.target: Block blobs larger than 64 MB must be uploaded as a set of blocks, each of which must be less than or equal to 4 MB in size.

trans-unit.source: A set of successfully uploaded blocks can be assembled in a specified order into a single contiguous blob by calling <link xlink:href="c864893e-d758-475a-b419-af0c60dd2569" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Put Block List</link>.
trans-unit.target: A set of successfully uploaded blocks can be assembled in a specified order into a single contiguous blob by calling <link xlink:href="c864893e-d758-475a-b419-af0c60dd2569" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Put Block List</link>.

trans-unit.source: The maximum size currently supported for a block blob is 200,000 MB.
trans-unit.target: The maximum size currently supported for a block blob is 200,000 MB.

trans-unit.source: Page blobs are created and initialized with a maximum size with a call to <link xlink:href="b213c30f-8d30-4718-ba77-2030f3009719" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Put Blob</link>.
trans-unit.target: Page blobs are created and initialized with a maximum size with a call to <link xlink:href="b213c30f-8d30-4718-ba77-2030f3009719" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Put Blob</link>.

trans-unit.source: To write content to a page blob, you call the <link xlink:href="ba36957a-ffd0-4080-8325-0fbb85d56330" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Put Page</link> operation.
trans-unit.target: To write content to a page blob, you call the <link xlink:href="ba36957a-ffd0-4080-8325-0fbb85d56330" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Put Page</link> operation.

trans-unit.source: The maximum size currently supported for a page blob is 1 TB.
trans-unit.target: The maximum size currently supported for a page blob is 1 TB.

trans-unit.source: Append blobs can be created by calling <link xlink:href="b213c30f-8d30-4718-ba77-2030f3009719" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Put Blob</link>.
trans-unit.target: Append blobs can be created by calling <link xlink:href="b213c30f-8d30-4718-ba77-2030f3009719" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Put Blob</link>.

trans-unit.source: An append blob created with the <link xlink:href="b213c30f-8d30-4718-ba77-2030f3009719" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Put Blob</link> operation does not include any content.
trans-unit.target: An append blob created with the <link xlink:href="b213c30f-8d30-4718-ba77-2030f3009719" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Put Blob</link> operation does not include any content.

trans-unit.source: To write content to an append blob, you add blocks to the end of the blob by calling the <link xlink:href="08d3ac04-23b4-4d39-9c40-06a38bdc6df1" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Append Block</link> operation.
trans-unit.target: To write content to an append blob, you add blocks to the end of the blob by calling the <link xlink:href="08d3ac04-23b4-4d39-9c40-06a38bdc6df1" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Append Block</link> operation.

trans-unit.source: Updating or deleting existing blocks is not supported.
trans-unit.target: Updating or deleting existing blocks is not supported.

trans-unit.source: Each block can be of different size, up to a maximum of 4 MB.
trans-unit.target: Each block can be of different size, up to a maximum of 4 MB.

trans-unit.source: The maximum size for a append blob is 200,000 MB, and an append blob can include no more than 50,000 blocks.
trans-unit.target: The maximum size for a append blob is 200,000 MB, and an append blob can include no more than 50,000 blocks.

trans-unit.source: Blobs support conditional update operations that may be useful for concurrency control and efficient uploading.
trans-unit.target: Blobs support conditional update operations that may be useful for concurrency control and efficient uploading.

trans-unit.source: Blobs can be read by calling the <link xlink:href="a3e943b4-5745-4e64-9d6f-728bbefbd5ee" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Get Blob</link> operation.
trans-unit.target: Blobs can be read by calling the <link xlink:href="a3e943b4-5745-4e64-9d6f-728bbefbd5ee" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Get Blob</link> operation.

trans-unit.source: A client may read the entire blob, or an arbitrary range of bytes.
trans-unit.target: A client may read the entire blob, or an arbitrary range of bytes.

trans-unit.source: For the Blob service API reference, see <link xlink:href="fa36aa0e-256a-488b-bc85-af7c3a230937" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Blob Service API</link>.
trans-unit.target: For the Blob service API reference, see <link xlink:href="fa36aa0e-256a-488b-bc85-af7c3a230937" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Blob Service API</link>.

trans-unit.source: Queue Service
trans-unit.target: Queue Service

trans-unit.source: The Queue service provides reliable, persistent messaging within and between services.
trans-unit.target: The Queue service provides reliable, persistent messaging within and between services.

trans-unit.source: The REST API for the Queue service exposes two resources: queues and messages.
trans-unit.target: The REST API for the Queue service exposes two resources: queues and messages.

trans-unit.source: Queues support user-defined metadata in the form of name-value pairs specified as headers on a request operation.
trans-unit.target: Queues support user-defined metadata in the form of name-value pairs specified as headers on a request operation.

trans-unit.source: Each storage account may have an unlimited number of message queues that are named uniquely within the account.
trans-unit.target: Each storage account may have an unlimited number of message queues that are named uniquely within the account.

trans-unit.source: Each message queue may contain an unlimited number of messages.
trans-unit.target: Each message queue may contain an unlimited number of messages.

trans-unit.source: The maximum size for a message is limited to 64KB for version 2011-08-18 and 8KB for previous versions.
trans-unit.target: The maximum size for a message is limited to 64KB for version 2011-08-18 and 8KB for previous versions.

trans-unit.source: When a message is read from the queue, the consumer is expected to process the message and then delete it.
trans-unit.target: When a message is read from the queue, the consumer is expected to process the message and then delete it.

trans-unit.source: After the message is read, it is made invisible to other consumers for a specified interval.
trans-unit.target: After the message is read, it is made invisible to other consumers for a specified interval.

trans-unit.source: If the message has not yet been deleted at the time the interval expires, its visibility is restored, so that another consumer may process it.
trans-unit.target: If the message has not yet been deleted at the time the interval expires, its visibility is restored, so that another consumer may process it.

trans-unit.source: For more information about the Queue service, see <link xlink:href="2793691c-e763-413d-93e7-e111312d5f4b" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Queue Service API</link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about the Queue service, see <link xlink:href="2793691c-e763-413d-93e7-e111312d5f4b" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Queue Service API</link>.

trans-unit.source: Table Service
trans-unit.target: Table Service

trans-unit.source: The Table service provides structured storage in the form of tables.
trans-unit.target: The Table service provides structured storage in the form of tables.

trans-unit.source: The Table service supports a REST API that implements the <externalLink><linkText>OData protocol</linkText><linkUri>http://www.odata.org/</linkUri></externalLink>.
trans-unit.target: The Table service supports a REST API that implements the <externalLink><linkText>OData protocol</linkText><linkUri>http://www.odata.org/</linkUri></externalLink>.

trans-unit.source: Within a storage account, a developer may create named tables.
trans-unit.target: Within a storage account, a developer may create named tables.

trans-unit.source: Tables store data as entities.
trans-unit.target: Tables store data as entities.

trans-unit.source: An entity is a collection of named properties and their values, similar to a row.
trans-unit.target: An entity is a collection of named properties and their values, similar to a row.

trans-unit.source: Tables are partitioned to support load balancing across storage nodes.
trans-unit.target: Tables are partitioned to support load balancing across storage nodes.

trans-unit.source: Each table has as its first property a partition key that specifies the partition an entity belongs to.
trans-unit.target: Each table has as its first property a partition key that specifies the partition an entity belongs to.

trans-unit.source: The second property is a row key that identifies an entity within a given partition.
trans-unit.target: The second property is a row key that identifies an entity within a given partition.

trans-unit.source: The combination of the partition key and the row key forms a primary key that identifies each entity uniquely within the table.
trans-unit.target: The combination of the partition key and the row key forms a primary key that identifies each entity uniquely within the table.

trans-unit.source: The Table service does not enforce any schema.
trans-unit.target: The Table service does not enforce any schema.

trans-unit.source: A developer may choose to implement and enforce a schema on the client side.
trans-unit.target: A developer may choose to implement and enforce a schema on the client side.

trans-unit.source: For more information about the Table service, see <link xlink:href="8e8a98bc-9cd0-42c2-b0aa-be6a4065c35c" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Table Storage API</link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about the Table service, see <link xlink:href="8e8a98bc-9cd0-42c2-b0aa-be6a4065c35c" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Table Storage API</link>.

trans-unit.source: File Service
trans-unit.target: File Service

trans-unit.source: The Server Message Block (SMB) protocol is the preferred file share protocol used on premise today.
trans-unit.target: The Server Message Block (SMB) protocol is the preferred file share protocol used on premise today.

trans-unit.source: The Microsoft Azure File service enables customers to leverage the availability and scalability of Azure’s Cloud Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) SMB without having to rewrite SMB client applications.
trans-unit.target: The Microsoft Azure File service enables customers to leverage the availability and scalability of Azure’s Cloud Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) SMB without having to rewrite SMB client applications.

trans-unit.source: The Azure File service also offers a compelling alternative to traditional Direct Attached Storage (DAS) and Storage Area Network (SAN) solutions, which are often complex and expensive to install, configure, and operate.
trans-unit.target: The Azure File service also offers a compelling alternative to traditional Direct Attached Storage (DAS) and Storage Area Network (SAN) solutions, which are often complex and expensive to install, configure, and operate.

trans-unit.source: Files stored in Azure File service shares are accessible via the SMB protocol, and also via REST APIs.
trans-unit.target: Files stored in Azure File service shares are accessible via the SMB protocol, and also via REST APIs.

trans-unit.source: The File service offers the following four resources: the storage account, shares, directories, and files.
trans-unit.target: The File service offers the following four resources: the storage account, shares, directories, and files.

trans-unit.source: Shares provide a way to organize sets of files and also can be mounted as an SMB file share that is hosted in the cloud.
trans-unit.target: Shares provide a way to organize sets of files and also can be mounted as an SMB file share that is hosted in the cloud.
